question.text: Two infinitely long straight wires lie in the xy - plane along the lines <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>±</mo><mi>R</mi></math>. The wire located at <math><mi>x</mi><mi> </mi><mo>=</mo><mi> </mi><mo>+</mo><mi>R</mi></math> carries a constant current <math><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math> and the wire located at <math><mi>x</mi><mi> </mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>R</mi></math> carries a constant current <math><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>. A circular loop of radius R is suspended with its centre at <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>0</mn><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt><mi>R</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> and in a plane parallel to the xy - plane. This loop carries a constant current <math><mi>I</mi></math> in the clockwise direction as seen from above the loop. The current in the wire is taken to be positive if it is in the <math><mo>+</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>j</mi></mrow><mo>^</mo></mover></math> direction. Which of the following statements regarding the magnetic field <math><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mover></math> is (are) true?

options.text: If <math><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi> </mi><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mover></math> cannot be equal to zero at the origin <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>

If <math><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi> </mi><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi> </mi><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mover></math> can be equal to zero at the origin <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>

If  <math><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi> </mi><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi> </mi><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mover></math>  can be equal to zero at the origin <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>

If <math><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> , Then the z-component of the magnetic field at the centre of the loop is \((-\mu 0 \mathrm{I} / 2 \mathrm{R})\)

solution.text: (A) At origin, B→=0 due to two wires if I1=I2, hence B→net at origin is equal to B→ due to ring, which is non-zero. (B) If I1>0 and I2<0,B→ at origin due to wires will be along +k^ direction and B→ due to ring is along -k^ direction and hence B→ can be zero at origin (C) If I1<0 and I2>0,B→ at origin due to wires is along -k^ and also along -k^ due to ring, hence B→ cannot be zero (D)
